title: Onomatopoeias 1
sentences: The dry branches were crackling in the fire.
The old clock was ticking loudly on the wall.
We heard the distant bells tolling.
The cat purred quietly in my lap.
The heavy stone made a big splash in the water.
The glass broke on the floor with a clatter.
The wind whistled/howled between the walls of the house.
The baby cooed happily in the crib.
Do you hear the train clicking/clattering on the rails?
The snake hissed loudly in the bush.
The birds were chirping happily on the tree.
The ice of the frozen lake gave a crack under my foot.
The distant thunder rumbled/growled above the mountains.
My shoe squeaked on the clean floor.
The bees were buzzing around the flowers.
The swords clashed/clattered in the heat of the battle.
Something rustled/clattered in the dark room.
The teapot whistled shrilly in the kitchen.
The brook gurgled/rippled quietly among the stones.
The rattle of machine guns broke the silence.
The metal gate screeched/grated when it was opened.
The crowd roared/hummed in the stadium.
The phone buzzed/purred quietly on the table.
A large piece of wood thudded on the ground.
The murmur/rumble of the audience drowned out the speaker's voice.
dictionary:
pattog - to crackle / pop
ketyeg - to tick
kondul - to toll / knell (bells)
dorombol - to purr
loccsan - to splash
csörömpöl - to clatter / jangle (glass/metal)
süvít - to whistle / howl (wind/bullet)
gőgicsél - to coo (baby)
kattog - to click / clatter (mechanical)
sziszeg - to hiss
csicsereg - to chirp
roppan - to crack / crunch
morog - to growl / rumble (thunder/dog)
nyikorog - to squeak / creak
zümmög - to buzz
csattog - to clash / clatter (swords/teeth)
zörren - to rustle / make a slight clatter
sipol - to whistle shrilly
csörgedezik - to gurgle / ripple
ropogás - rattle / crackling
csikorog - to screech / grate (metal on metal)
zúg - to roar / hum / buzz
berreg - to buzz / whir
koppan - to thud / clink (hard object hitting surface)
morajlás - murmur / rumble
